title: Tuesday, 19th September, 2017

PM11:07am

So, Markets

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Yes! Markets!

BE11:08am

It's a wee bit "spot the story" this morning.

BE11:09am

Seem to have used up all the news yesterday. So, we have sterling doing not much .....

11:09 am
BE11:09am

FTSE drifting higher without much trend

BE11:10am

Ahead 25 points at 7278 at pixel

BE11:10am

And with a comforting familiarity, we have a rubbish statement from Ocado.

11:10 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 282.28, down 19.72 (-6.53%), High: 298.90, Low: 280.00, Volume: 2.70m
BE11:11am

Don't worry about sales growth! Sales, they're still growing.

BE11:11am

The cost of growing sales, though? Well, not so great.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Let's cut to Goldman to take us through the figures, since Goldman is not so much Ocado's house broker as its embedded communications department.

BE11:13am

Ocado (CL-Buy) reported 3Q17 Retail revenue growth (excluding Morrison contribution) of +13.1%, slightly ahead of our estimate/Bloomberg consensus of +12.7%/+13.0%. Group revenue (including M.com) grew +14.3% yoy to £345mn vs our estimate of +12.9%. In the release, management also highlighted an increase in short term costs relating to new CFCs, which we believe will have a small negative impact on consensus EBITDA estimates.

BE11:13am

Average orders per week: grew +16% yoy to 254,000 orders vs GSe +16%. This is strong volume growth in a period where implied volume growth for the market ex-discounters was -1.1% (Kantar, 12 weeks to August 13).
Average order size: on the core Ocado.com grocery site average order size declined -1.2% to £106.25, and declined by -2.0% to £103.04 and including the impact of standalone orders through Fetch, Sizzle, Fabled and wholesale partnerships. This is vs average ONS Food inflation from June-August of +2.6%, but compares favourably to the same period last year (3Q16) when Ocado.com basket size was -3.4% (and Group average basket size was -4.5%).

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Net debt: As of August 27, 2017, the Group had cash and cash equivalents of £148.9mn (1H17: £37.8mn or £174mn post financing) and external borrowings of £284.1mn (1H17: £140.2mn or £276mn post financing). This implies an increase in net debt of £33mn, in line with the cash usage in 1Q17, driven by Ocado’s investments in both CFC3 and CFC4.

BE11:14am

CFC3 Andover/CFC 4 Erith and cost increases: Ocado state they are scaling up capacity in CFC3 “with the performance of the facility improving week by week”. Alongside the preparation of Erith (CFC4) which set to open in 2018 (as per previous guidance), management note that these investments will “increase some costs in the short term”.

BE11:15am

Implications
Given management’s comments on an increase in short term costs, we expect low single digit downward revisions to Bloomberg consensus EBITDA, which currently sits at £93.5mn. While the sales performance continues to be strong and we do not believe short term cost increases have a negative bearing on the Ocado investment case, given the shares are +13% YTD vs European food retail average of -4% , we believe the stock is likely to slightly underperform following this release.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

A reminder that you'd hope CFC3's performance is improving "week by week" .....

BE11:16am

.... because previously, CFC3 was having to get its deliveries from CFC2 in Dordon.

BE11:16am

https://www.ft.com...-a3f4-c742b9791d43

11:17 am
BE11:17am

... because about 90% of its capacity was idle and the people who deliver cornflakes won't deliver for such small volumes.

BE11:17am

Anyway, have another buyer.

BE11:17am

Citi this time.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Citi forecasts unchanged but c.£2m additional ramp up costs temper consensus EBITDA – Mindful of the necessary costs of starting and scaling operations in the first of its second generation warehouses (CFC3 at Andover) we initiated with an FY16/17 EBITDA forecast of £88.6m vs. consensus £92.8m. Comments on today’s investor c-call suggest that these costs (temporary engineer costs) will see the mean consensus move towards £90-91m.

BE11:18am

Second Generation warehouse scaling successfully – Commentary of the investor call suggested the capacity of Andover’s CFC3 has doubled since the end of the first half, such that we would now estimate a capacity of c.30% (from. c.15%). Moreover, Andover’s CFC is now running simultaneous inbound and outbound operations, successfully doubling the workload of the robots.

BE11:19am

mazon-Whole Foods highlighted among positive catalysts – Although Amazon’s grocery penetration is presently low and its prices above its mainstream grocery peers, Ocado highlighted Amazon’s acquisition of Whole Foods as a positive catalyst for its Ocado Smart Platform solution for third party retailers. However, it also called out the opportunities from showcasing the successful launch of Andover’s CFC3 and the allocation of greater resource to the sales and marketing of the OSP solution.

11:18 am
undefined
BE11:19am

ROTR are straight into Toys R Us, I see .........

BE11:20am

Which is not a death of retail story.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

It's a "leveraged buyouts kill companies" story.

BE11:20am

https://twitter.com/pareene/status/909995717120405505

BE11:22am

The FTAV internal slackchat spent a while on toy stores this morning, with a sharp divide between the people with children (who hate Toys R Us) and those without (who hold some kind of nostalgic affection).

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Fact is, Toys R Us is a dreadful place to shop.

BE11:23am

The stores haven't been freshened in decades, the stock is lying around in a mess, the demonstration tablets are all broken .....

BE11:24am

..... and as you head to the till they try and gouge you six different ways, with Star Wars bags and club memberships and junk.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

It takes a lot to make a toy store where children don't want to go, but somehow they managed under PE ownership.

BE11:24am

So ........... not Amazon. Just barbarians. Same old same old.

undefined
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Okay, back to London then.

BE11:26am

Stagecoach mentioned on the right.

Stagecoach Group PLC (SGC:LSE): Last: 167.14, up 7.94 (+4.99%), High: 168.00, Low: 159.10, Volume: 1.69m
11:26 am
BE11:26am

That's off a ....... 52 week low, I think? Or close to.

BE11:27am

Liberum calling the bottom.

BE11:28am

(@BornCynic: market reporting is by its nature a rear view mirror, no matter how much we try to pretend it's not.)

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Stagecoach still faces challenges in current trading and the risk of re-regulation in parts of the regional bus industry. The underperformance of the East Coast rail franchise continues to dominate sentiment. In our view, there is scope for a deal to relieve the pressure on the group, although the politics are difficult to navigate. However, we see the risks as evenly balanced at the current valuation, with our forecasts showing a dividend yield of 7.7% matching the P/E of 7.7x. Consequently we upgrade our recommendation to HOLD from Sell, with an unchanged SOTP-based target price of 155p.

BE11:28am

Industry conditions remain challenging

Revenue growth in the Regional Bus industry remains elusive. Capacity and cost cuts have seen Stagecoach defend margins at levels that remain respectable (2018E: 11.9%), while well down on historic levels (peak: 17.9%). However, more aggressive cuts would risk handing ammunition to critics pursuing re-regulation. Although the risks in this area have moderated, the prospect of re-regulation in Manchester remains live, with a material downside risk to market share and margins, along with the potential for other cities to follow suit.

London is facing competitive pressures on tender pricing, a trend which was echoed recently by Go-Ahead, which is the leader in that market. Labour cost inflation is also a challenge, with wages being the largest component of the division's cost structure.

Meanwhile, rail passenger volume growth continues to slow. The series of recent terrorist attacks is unhelpful and unlikely to help the recovery of discretionary travel into London. The East Coast franchise is the most exposed, although the onerous contract provision ought to mean that the income statement is unaffected.

BE11:29am

(@Mouselet: I'd suggest it's the former. B&M's predatory thing of putting toys on the high level of the grocery bit is evil genius. No one who worked shopfloor at Toys R Us over the past decade has been a genius, though I guess the evil bit is a matter of debate.)

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We believe the underperformance of the East Coast rail franchise continues to dominate sentiment towards Stagecoach. Slower than anticipated revenue growth has seen the group miss its bid assumptions, with the rising premium payments stipulated in the contract putting the bottom line under pressure. At the FY results in June, the group took an onerous contract provision of £84m to cover a pessimistic projection of the operating losses for the next two years. The group remains exposed to the cash flow variations over this period, but the income statement is protected so long as the losses do not exceed the provision.

In our view, there is scope for a deal to relieve the pressure on the group, although the politics are difficult to navigate. In its franchise bid, Stagecoach relied on additional and enhanced capacity becoming available at East Coast from 2019. These improvements were expected to help generate significant revenue growth. The assumption of such growth allowed Stagecoach to commit to pay higher premium payments to the DfT. It is now widely accepted that Network Rail (which is owned by the government) will be unable to deliver the necessary infrastructure improvements on time or to specification. We believe this forms the basis for a variation to the East Coast franchise contract, to reflect the current reality of infrastructure capacity.

However, from a political point of view, we would expect the DfT to be keen to avoid any perception of a bail out of a private sector operator. This complicates the execution of negotiations, and the timing thereof, but it does not alter the underlying basis for revisions. Clarity on contract revisions could be a material positive catalyst for Stagecoach.

BE11:30am

Despite our concerns about earnings momentum, industry headwinds and bus re-regulation, we believe these risks are now better reflected in the current share price. The shares have fallen 28% over the past year and 10% over the past month, leaving Stagecoach trading on an April 2018E P/E of 7.7x, EV/EBITDA of 4.5x (ex-rail cash) and 7.7% dividend yield.

The near cross over between the dividend yield and P/E is relatively noteworthy. However, we continue to highlight that conventional earnings multiples are not particularly informative due to the finite nature of rail earnings, along with a substantial onerous contract provision having been booked for the East Coast franchise, removing trading losses from the income statement.

We view the dividend yield as sustainable, with non-rail dividend cover of 1.2x on April 2018E estimates, and improving thereafter. FCF cover is below 1.0x in the short term, but the balance sheet has headroom to fund the dividend through debt. Leverage remains acceptable (April 2018E: headline net debt/EBITDA 1.7x, ex-rail cash 2.0x), and although the worst case scenario of default on the East Coast franchise would stress the balance sheet, we would expect leverage to remain below 3.0x, still well within the covenant maximum of 3.5x.

Overall, we see the risks as evenly balanced at the current valuation, and so upgrade our recommendation to HOLD from Sell, with an unchanged target price of 155p, based on our sum-of-the-parts valuation (rounded down).

BE11:31am

Hm .......... 7.7 is cheap for what is in effect a government outsourcer.

STATEMENTS OF INTENTION AND

11:37 am
PM11:37am

BE11:37am

Nuts.

PM11:37am

11:37 am

undefined

So ......... what else?

11:39 am
BE11:40am

....... wow, there really isn't much going on.

BE11:40am

Request earlier for GKP of all things.

Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 119.44, down 5.06 (-4.07%), High: 122.75, Low: 116.50, Volume: 424.22k
11:40 am
BE11:40am

It's above a penny again!

BE11:41am

As in old form, pre consolidation. So, interims are okayish.

PM11:42am

Interims here https://www.invest...1709190700070976R/

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Gross production of nearly 37k barrels a day is a slight improvement on H1 and the cash is gradually repairing the balance sheet.

BE11:43am

The company continues to live hand to mouth, of course, and Kurdistan's referendum is not an insignificant overhang for that .....

BE11:43am

.... but you can make a buy case nevertheless. Well, Peel Hunt can.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Operating profit of $6.3m was slightly ahead of our forecasts, which look for $8.1m for FY2017. Substantially reduced G&A of $9.7m was also in line with our expectations of $20m in 2017E. This fed through to help generate cash flow from operations of $30.1m, which again is in line with our full-year forecast of $66.6m.

BE11:44am

The current main focus for management is to achieve a successful outcome to the ongoing discussions with the Ministry of Natural Resources (MNR) around ratification of Gulf Keystone’s amended PSC. In this regard, a positive statement was made, “the Board is confident they (commercial and contractual discussions) will be concluded in the near future”. As and when this occurs, we highlight it as an event that will likely be materially supportive for shareholders as it will pave the way for rapid subsequent investment into Shaikan, which will in turn result in increased production to 40,000bbl/d before rising to 55,000bbl/d and beyond with additional investment.

BE11:44am

Valuation and recommendation. A good steady set of results this morning is exactly what was needed. All key metrics were broadly in line with our expectations, so we currently leave our full-year production and financial forecasts unchanged. However, should the Shaikan field continue to perform as well as it has done year to date, it is likely that we will make upgrades during Q4. In terms of NAV, our current assessment of Shaikan values Gulf Keystone’s operated interest at £548m, equivalent to 237p/share. Adjusting for improved balance sheet strength where over the past six months cash has increased from $92.9m to $133.8m, we move our target price upwards and in line with our Core NAV, which now stands at £565m, or 245p/share

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Gulf Keystone is at an exciting stage in its development and sits poised ready to make the necessary capital investments to enable marked production ramp up. With regards to the ongoing commercial discussions with the MNR, we are optimistic of a timely resolution in the coming months. With these key factors in mind we are confident reiterating our buy recommendation and as the business continues to make steady progress developing the world class Shaikan oil field expect the shares to perform well.

BE11:45am

Fair enough to be a wee bit cautious around NAVs for Shaikan. We've been down that road a few times over the past decade.

undefined
11:46 am
PM11:47am

Seen this BreX-files stuff from Merrill?

PM11:47am

They've really gone to town

PM11:47am

Well, Tommy Ricketts has at ML

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Oh, glanced at it yesterday. Anything worth picking out?

PM11:47am

Ah, didnt see it yesterday

PM11:48am

Here are the takeaways..

11:47 am
PM11:48am

The BreX-files series delves into post-Brexit Britain and what leaving on WTO-terms could mean for the UK economy & sectors.
Key findings: some UK stocks harder to broke; BoE policies aiding consumer cyclicals; Staples least, Airlines most sensitive.
Net outward migration is a major risk for some sectors; house prices/ lending conditions/ access to talent/ wages.

PM11:48am

But there are 11 parts to it

PM11:48am

Our UK Strategist, Tommy Ricketts, summarises in The BreX-files: Series Digest the findings of a series of interviews with BofAML's UK-focused fundamental equity research analysts on post-Brexit Britain. In them, we take stock of developments 15 months after the vote. We also undertake a granular discussion of a scenario in which the UK leaves the EU on World Trade Organisation (WTO) terms and what this could mean for UK plc, companies, and the economy. While extreme, and not our base case, exploring this tail risk brings the challenges facing post-Brexit Britain into sharp relief.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

And 9 things that ML thinks investors should know...

PM11:49am

1. Broking some UK-listed stocks is now harder, especially to international investors.
2. A "bonfire" of red tape is hard to envisage given lead role of UK agencies.
3. Onerous changes to ownership rules could stifle M&A activity.
4. Bank of England (BoE) policies are propping up growth/ consumer cyclicals.
5. Economic fallout from a WTO-exit is dependent on the "kindness of strangers".
6. Disconnect between listed UK and UK plc may widen further.
7. Net outward migration post-Brexit is a major risk for companies.
8. A WTO Brexit scenario would be least problematic for Miners/ Staples, most for Airlines.
9. Fundamentals still trump Brexit as a driver for UK equity returns, for now.

PM11:50am

The Brexit Bull-Bear guide
We think the investment conclusion for UK equities is fairly clear for investors wishing to take a direction view on Brexit: the better the prospective trade deal, the more-GBP positive FX investors treat it, the more likely rates markets are to start pricing in BoE hikes, the stronger the case for rotating into UK consumer cyclicals and/ or long duration sectors, especially Real Estate and significant underperformers such as Media and Retailers. Investors bearish on the outcome, and that need to be invested in the UK, should seek shelter in Basic Resources, Oil majors, Consumer Staples, and Healthcare.

11:49 am
PM11:50am

That'll do

undefined
BE11:51am

Should probably mention the grocers.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Should probably have mentioned them with Ocado earlier, but I forgot. Anyway, it's Kantar time again.

BE11:51am

Big news is that inflation's eased a tad.

BE11:52am

Only running at 3.2% for the most recent 12 weeks, versus 3.3% in last month's reading.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Which is great because wage inflation's running at ... oh wait .... anyway, have a chart.

BE11:52am

BE11:53am

So ........ in terms of the big four. Usual story really.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Key numbers (on a four-week Till Roll basis):

· Tesco: -15bps (vs -12bps last time)

· Sainsbury: -9bps (vs -30bps last time)

· Morrison: -7bps (vs +1bps last time)

· ASDA: -18bps (vs -20bps last time)

· Aldi & Lidl: +93bps (vs +116bps last time)

BE11:54am

And a few bullet points from Barclays.

BE11:54am

This is the first time since November 2015 that inflation has moved in a downward direction.

· This is the sixth consecutive month in which the market has growth by more than 3% (on a 12 week basis). Kantar notes that sustained market growth of this kind has not been seen since May 2013.

· On a four week basis, all of the big four except Morrison posted sales growth ahead of the mechanical expectation based on last year’s comps. They all posted market share declines in the four week period, however Sainsbury and ASDA posted share losses which were better than the mechanical expectation.

· The discounters’ combined sales growth in the four weeks to 10 September was 14.8%, which is below the 16.7% in the previous month. This is also the slowest growth month for the discounters since January 2017.

11:54 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 242.80, up 5.8 (+2.45%), High: 243.40, Low: 235.70, Volume: 2.45m
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 186.35, up 2.5 (+1.36%), High: 186.60, Low: 182.55, Volume: 7.63m
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 234.70, up 3.6 (+1.56%), High: 236.60, Low: 227.90, Volume: 4.37m
11:55 am
BE11:55am

And Morgan Stanley .........

BE11:56am

Inflation remains high, impacting shoppers' spending patterns. Grocery inflation was up +3.2% YoY in September (12 weeks trailing). We assume this is mostly a function of Brexit-induced input cost inflation. This is currently leading to shoppers trading down in-stores: over the past 12 weeks, consumer spend on supermarkets' own-label products rose +5.5% YoY, nearly five time the growth in spend on branded products (up only +1.2% YoY). It is also translating to an acceleration in the channel shift in favor of hard discounters: Aldi and Lidl's combined sales grew +16.7% YoY in September vs. +4.2% YoY in November 2016

BE11:56am

However, inflation has started to (slightly) moderate. While inflation remains elevated by historical standards, its is nevertheless moderating, for the first time in about two years (inflation was up +3.3% YoY in August - 12 weeks training). This is likely due to the industry lapping the Brexit vote (June 2016) and its impact on FX. With the GBP strengthening against the USD and the Euro in recent weeks, one could assume that grocery inflation should moderate further. Potentially as a result of moderating inflation, hard discounters' share gains slow down (slightly) in September: Aldi and Lidl's gained +120 bps of market share in September vs. +150 bps in August and +160 bps in July (Lidl's increased share gains did not offset Aldi's slow down.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

M&S and Waitrose sequentially better. At the other end of the market, both M&S and Waitrose fared better this month, with a combined outperformance of +100 bps vs. the market in September vs. +80 bps in August and -260 bps in July.
Mixed performance by the 'Big Four'. While Tesco continued to lose market share in grocery over the past there months (-40 bps YoY), these market share losses moderated and Kantar data implies UK LFL sales up c.+3.1% in 2Q18 vs. +2.3% reported in 1Q18. Sainsbury's performance remained weak in P9, potentially a function of the Group moving to a more Every Day Low Price (EDLP) positioning. Morrisons' underperformance vs. the overall market increased slightly sequentially (vs. August), but was in line with the performance YTD

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 338.28, up 9.68 (+2.95%), High: 338.50, Low: 328.70, Volume: 2.51m
